newsitem.title: SWITZERLAND: OSCE envoy-West's troops must stay in Bosnia.
newsitem.headline: OSCE envoy-West's troops must stay in Bosnia.

text.p: Europe's security envoy to Bosnia called on Saturday for a Western peacekeeping presence to stay in the divided country for the "indefinite future" to handle a potentially explosive situation.

"The international community has to stay there for years to help stabilise the situation," said Robert Frowick, head of the Organisation for Security and Cooperation in Europe (OSCE) mission to Bosnia.

"Both civil and the military need to commit for the indefinite future. We have to commit to a significant number," he told a news conference during an international business forum in the Swiss mountain resort of Crans Montana.
"These people were engaged in genocide. What happened in Sarajevo can happen again if we're not careful."
The 35,00-strong NATO-led peace force SFOR (Stabilisation Force) is due to leave in June 1998. It replaced the NATO-led Implementation Force which at its height had 60,000 troops.
Frowick, whose organisation is also overseeing Bosnia's local polls in September, said it was up to Western commanders to decide the size of a future force, but stressed that it had to be credible.
"This force has to be able to fulfil a strategy of flexible response. I see no reason why the countries involved with the resources they have can't be brought to do this," he said.
"To be credible it has to be clear that it's backed up by air power and if need be by sea power with cruise missiles to meet any threat."
Frowick said the OSCE, whose mandate expires at the end of this year, could end up staying "for years" in Bosnia. "There is no way the OSCE can leave that country in 1998," he said.

He said the single biggest obstacle to the success of the U.S.-brokered Dayton peace accord that ended the 1992-1995 war was the the lack of political will to arrest leading suspects indicted by the U.N. criminal tribunal for former Yugoslavia.

"According to the rules of the game that we have now, the parties are supposed to have their police go arrest them. But this is a complete illusion. Something needs to be done -- an international police effort of some kind," Frowick said.
"The viability of the peace process depends on bringing war criminals to justice. As long as they stay there, there will be ultra-nationalism undermining the peace process."
The NATO troops have refused to round up war crimes suspects who continue to work in positions of power.
The two most prominent suspects, former Bosnian Serb president Radovan Karadzic and former Bosnian Serb military commander Ratko Mladic, still remain at large.

The United States, Britain, France and other troop-contributing countries have been urged to arrest indicted war criminals, and have considered sending in "snatch squads", but they fear this could cause security problems for their troops.
